questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a painless, bluish, fluctuant and translucent swelling on the lower lip that enlarges with eating or pressure, as shown in the image below. She reports a history of accidentally biting her lip frequently. What histopathological feature would be expected on biopsy of the lesion?

choices.text: Mucin-filled cavity surroundedby granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells.
Proliferation of ductal cells within fibrous connective tissue
Epithelial dysplasia and atypical cells.
Eosinophilic granuloma with multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mucin-filled cavity surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells.

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and the image suggest Mucocele, a benign cystic lesion caused by the accumulation of saliva due to trauma or obstruction of the salivary gland duct.
Histologically, it is characterized by a mucin-filled cavity without an epithelial lining (in the extravasation type), surrounded by granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory cells, especially macrophages (mucinophages).

  • Mucin-filled cavity incites an inflammatory response, and for the repair of this, the body will start making granulation tissue.
  • A mucocele is an extravasation cyst: Due to excessive lip biting or any trauma, accumulation of lots of saliva and mucus occurs, resulting in a cystic lesion.
  • It does not have any ductal epithelium or ductal lining. A true cyst lined by ductal epithelium.

Treatment:

  • Cryotherapy
  • Laser Treatment
  • Surgical Excision: Removal of the cyst

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a slowly growing painless mass in her left parotid gland region that has been present for several months. On examination, a firm, mobile, non-tender mass is palpable in the preauricular area. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals epithelial and myoepithelial cells in a chondromyxoid background. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pleomorphic adenoma
Warthin tumor
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
Adenoid cystic carcinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

Type of tumour

  • More common in females

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing mass in her left parotid gland. Examination reveals a firm, mobile mass. Biopsy confirms pleomorphic adenoma with characteristic islands of cartilage and foci of bone in a myxoid stroma. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Mostly found in the parotid gland
Mixed tumours with ductal, myoepithelial and mesenchymal cells
Radiation exposure is a risk factor
Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Down-regulation of PLAG1 results in abnormal cell proliferation

Explanation:

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign mixed tumor predominantly of the parotid gland and is commonly seen in females.

  • It contains both epithelial (ductal and myoepithelial) and mesenchymal components (myxoid, chondroid, and osseous tissue).

  • Radiation exposure is a known risk factor for salivary gland tumors, including pleomorphic adenoma.

  • The PLAG1 (PLAG= Pleomorphic Adenoma Gene) gene is an oncogene, and up-regulation or overexpression (not down-regulation) of PLAG1 leads to abnormal cell proliferation and tumorigenesis in pleomorphic adenoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the left parotid gland over several years. Examination reveals a firm, mobile, non-tender mass. Histological findings confirm pleomorphic adenoma. Which factor is associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenomas?

choices.text: Younger age of the patient
Larger size of the tumour
Increased age of the lesion
Presence of hyalinized stroma within the tumour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased age of the lesion.

 

Explanation:

Rates of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenoma correlate with the age of the lesion

  • When the age of pleomorphic adenoma's lesion exceeds 15-20 years, the chances of malignant transformations increase: Carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma (Carcinoma has originated inside a pre-existing pleomorphic adenoma).

Pleomorphic adenoma

  • It is a benign mixed tumor
  • Most common salivary gland tumor and most commonly occurs in the parotid.
  • Mostly seen in females.
  • On FNAC or biopsy: It shows epithelial and mesenchymal cells (mixed tumor)
    • Epithelial components: Epithelia, myoepithelial and ductal cells
    • Mesenchymal tissue comprise of chondromyxoid stroma

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker presents with a painless swelling in the parotid region. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals murky fluid. Which of the following histopathological features is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Proliferation of squamous epithelial cells with keratinisation
Oncocytic cells with double-layered lining
Neuroendocrine differentiation
Papillary architecture with psammoma bodies

questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation (history of chronic smoking) and histopathological image (Murky fluid on FNAC) suggest a Warthin tumour or Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, a benign salivary gland tumour that typically occurs in the parotid gland.
  • On histopathology it is characterised by:
    • Pink coloured oncocytic cells, which are double-layered.
    • Deep blue coloured lymphocytes.
  • Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum:
    • Papillary: Shows papillary projections
    • Cyst: Cyst which is filled with murky fluid which is aspirated on FNAC.
    • Adenoma: Because it is a benign tumor
    • Lymphomatosum: It contains significant lymphoid components.
  • It is seen in chronic smokers and commonly involves bilateral parotid glands.
  • This characteristic appearance is often referred to as "Cystic oncocytic hyperplasia."

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Proliferation of squamous epithelial cells with keratinisation (Option A): Seen in pleomorphic adenoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Warthin's tumour is true?

choices.text: It is the most common malignant tumour of the salivary glands.
They are typically located in the parotid gland.
It is more common in females.
Associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) They Are typically located in the parotid gland.

Explanation:

Warthin tumour or Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is a benign salivary gland tumour primarily affecting the parotid gland.

  • It is more common in males and is strongly associated with a history of smoking.
  • Parotid involvement can be bilateral.
  • On FNAC, Murky fluid is aspirated.
  • Histopathological features:
    • Shows papillary projections
    • It is a benign tumour with cyst formation.
    • Cells: Double-layered pink-coloured oncocytic cells and a lot of lymphocytic infiltrates.

It is the most common malignant tumour of the salivary glands (Option A): Warthin tumour is a benign tumour

It is more common in females (Option C): It is more common in males, especially with a history of smoking.

Associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (Option D): It is associated with heavy chronic smoking.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a slow-growing painless mass in the left submandibular gland region. Imaging studies reveal a solid lesion with cystic components. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) shows a mixture of mucin-producing, epidermoid, and intermediate cells. A histopathology image is given below. Which of the following features is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most commonly found in the sublingual salivary glands.
Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation.
Encapsulated tumours.
Histologically characterized by the presence of spindle cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Most are associated with a (11;19) translocation.

Explanation:

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (MEC):

  • It is the most common malignant tumour of salivary glands, often found in parotid and submandibular glands. (Option A)
  • It does not have a capsule (Option C)
  • It is associated with the (11;19) chromosomal translocation, creating CRTC1-MAML2 fusion protein.
  • Histologically, it exhibits squamous and mucous cell features. (Option D)
  • There are 3 types of cells in Mucoepidermoid carcinoma:
    • Mucus-producing cells
    • Epidermoid or Squamoid cells
    • Intermediate cells.
  • Grading: 
    • Low grade MEC: If mucus component is predominant.
    • High grade MEC: If epidermoid or squamoid component is predominant.

Image: Low-power view showing sheets and micro cysts containing cells of varying morphologies in Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a slowly enlarging painless mass in the right parotid gland region. Imaging studies reveal a solid tumour with a characteristic "Swiss cheese" appearance on MRI. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) shows basaloid cells with cribriform and tubular patterns. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most commonly occur in the parotid and submandibular glands.
MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in all cases
Encapsulated lesions with a smooth surface.
Tend to grow rapidly and have a high mitotic rate.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Most commonly occur in the parotid and submandibular glands.

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and characteristic ‘Swiss cheese’ appearance on MRI with basaloid cells and cribriform pattern on FNAC suggest Adenoid cystic carcinoma, which most commonly affects parotid and submandibular glands.


Cribriform pattern in a salivary gland tumor always tells us about Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma.

 

MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in all cases (Option B)
MYB-NFIB gene rearrangements are present in a subset of adenoid cystic carcinomas and not in all cases.

Encapsulated lesions with a smooth surface (Option C)
It is poorly capsulated

Tend to grow rapidly and have a high mitotic rate (Option D)
Adenoid cystic carcinomas are slow-growing tumours that tend to invade perineural spaces (therefore painful lesions), indicating a low mitotic rate.

 

Image: Three typical growth patterns, including cribriform (left), tubular (center), and solid (right).
